items.title: Thailand, Cambodia sign new ceasefire deal to end weeks of border fighting
items.summary_auto: Thailand and Cambodia on Saturday signed a ceasefire agreement to end weeks of armed combat along their border over competing claims to territory. It took effect at noon local time.

items.title: Navy ponders concept of Canadian-built amphibious landing ship for Arctic operations
items.summary_auto: With Canada ramping up defence spending, the navy is looking at how it can move equipment and personnel quickly throughout the Arctic and the world. The answer might be an amphibious landing ship, says the commander of the Royal Canadian Navy.

items.title: World Cup tickets in Toronto are expensive to begin with. Ontario's resale regulations don't help
items.summary_auto: With tickets to next year's six World Cup games in Toronto selling out as quickly as they're released, the only option for most soccer fans is the resale market. But a 2019 decision by the Ontario government has allowed tickets to those matches, and other major events, to go sky high.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | 2025's top Canadian images
items.summary_auto: There was no shortage of top Canadian newsmakers in 2025. Here's a look at this year's 100 memorable moments by CBC photographers, videographers and others.

items.title: Political control over ancient sites sparks alarm in Ontario
items.summary_auto: In Ontario, where ancient Indigenous burial grounds and village sites lie beneath rapidly expanding suburbs, the government has granted itself powers to bypass archaeological protections, raising fears that centuries of history could be lost with the stroke of a minister’s pen.

items.title: Test your Canadian politics knowledge with The House's 2025 year-end quiz
items.summary_auto: See how you measure up by following along with 40 of this year's questions below, as prepared by quizmaster Emma Godmere.

items.title: Annette Dionne, last of the famed Canadian quintuplets, dies at 91
items.summary_auto: After she and her siblings were taken from their parents in the 1930s and put on display for tourists, Annette Dionne became a champion of children's rights. She died on Christmas Eve, according to The Dionne Quints Home Museum in North Bay, Ont.

items.title: Canada holds off Czechs in wild opener of men’s junior hockey worlds
items.summary_auto: Ethan MacKenzie scored the game-winning goal in the third period as Canada opened the world junior hockey championship with a nervy 7-5 victory over the Czech Republic on Friday.

items.title: Group of asylum seekers arrested in Montérégie, Que.
items.summary_auto: Nineteen asylum seekers of Haitian origin were arrested Thursday night in the Havelock area of Montérégie, Que., according to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

items.title: Rare painted bunting sighting a 'Christmas gem' for some N.B. birders
items.summary_auto: The painted bunting usually calls the southern U.S. home and travels south at this time of year, but one decided to spend its Christmas holidays up north in Bayfield, N.B.
